author: m.kalinin
content: Personally, I am open for withdrawals right at the Merge. But the complexity of its implementation makes me think about the following trade off. We ship the Merge without withdrawals about 3 months earlier than if withdrawals were included. They are not that simple as it might seem from the first glance and require EVM opcode and system contract or an alternative to the latter. It will take additional time to test and reason about these changes. And the preference is to work on withdrawals in parallel to the general Merge line but not bundle them with already complicated network upgrade.

author: m.kalinin
content: Btw, 3 months is not a certain amount of time required for developing and testing withdrawals. It may vary and used as an example in the message about. But this number is certainly more than 3 days or 3 weeks.

author: ajsutton
content:
There is definitely a constant stream of upgrades to deal with and I can very much sympathise with being a new client trying to play catch-up while Ethereum keeps moving the goal posts forward. Been there, done that and it‚Äôs brutal. 
But at the same time if we don‚Äôt push hard to keep Ethereum moving forward the timelines just keep blowing out further and further. No one is suggesting we ship the merge this year regardless and I think everyone sees it as optimistic (and getting less and less likely as time progresses without Altair and London fully wrapped up). But we need to be able to keep Ethereum moving forward constantly while teams work out how to keep up and perform other improvements at the same time.
But while pushing hard we still need to keep timelines flexible so if things take longer we ship later and just be ok with that. We don‚Äôt sacrifice quality (and I don‚Äôt think we are currently).

author: timbeiko
content:
I'm happy to help play a role here. As <@!340345049063882753> said, though, it's a fine balance. In a lot of my conversations about 1559, miners thought it was straight up impossible the merge would happen in less than 2 years and several people are still under the impression that the "original" Eth2 roadmap (merge after Phase 2) is the right one. 

There's a lot of nuance to the message, but one thing I've been saying is that people should **not** start mining now with the expectation they have a >12 mo ROI window. In a way, the more conservative estimates we give to miners, the more optimistic estimates we give to everyone else üòÖ

author: timbeiko
